title: Bacterial blight
subtitle: Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae
desc: Bacterial blight is caused by Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae.  It causes wilting of seedlings and yellowing and drying of leaves. Check for wilting and yellowing of leaves, or wilting of seedlings (also called kresek).

title: Blast
subtitle: Magnaporthe grisea
desc: Blast is caused by the fungus Magnaporthe oryzae. It can affect all above ground parts of a             rice plant: leaf, collar, node, neck, parts of panicle, and sometimes leaf sheath. Initial symptoms appear as white to gray-green lesions or spots, with dark green borders.

title: Brown Spot
subtitle: Cochliobolus miyabeanus
desc: Brown spot has been historically largely ignored as one of the most common and most damaging rice diseases. Infected seedlings have small, circular, yellow brown or brown lesions that may girdle the coleoptile and distort primary and secondary leaves. Starting at tillering stage, lesions can be observed on the leaves. They are initially small, circular, and dark brown to purple-brown.

title: Sheath Blight
subtitle: Rhizoctonia solani Kühn
desc: Sheath blight is a fungal disease caused by Rhizoctonia solani. Infected leaves senesce or dry out and die more rapidly, young tillers can also be destroyed. oval or ellipsoidal greenish gray lesions, usually 1-3 cm long, on the leaf sheath, initially just above the soil or water level in the case of conventionally flooded rice.
